examples.title: Three-Phase Voltage Monitor (Multi-Source, Mixed Backends)
examples.description: Real-world example monitoring 3-phase voltage from both MongoDB and InfluxDB buckets. Demonstrates multiple data sources with different backends and backend-specific tags.
examples.use_case: Industrial power monitoring, electrical substations, energy management systems
customization_notes: Replace 'power_monitors' with your product ID
Update 'em2101_data_bucket' and 'Dispro_PSP' with your bucket IDs
Change 'voltageL1N', 'V2', 'V3' mappings to your field names
Adjust colors (#2E93fA, #66DA26, #ff8800) for visual distinction
Modify backend from 'mongodb'/'influxdb' based on your setup
Update 'user' field with actual username
Adapt tags structure to match your backend configuration
For InfluxDB: adjust custom tags (Day, Hour, Slave, tag1, tag2)
For MongoDB: use device and group tags
Adjust timespan values (24 hours) based on monitoring needs
Change layout position (col, row) and size (sizeX, sizeY) as needed

examples.title: Simple Temperature Chart (Single Source)
examples.description: Basic temperature monitoring chart with single data source from MongoDB bucket. Ideal for getting started with dashboard widgets.
examples.use_case: Environmental monitoring, HVAC systems, cold chain logistics, building automation
customization_notes: Replace 'temperature_sensors' with your product ID
Update 'temperature_bucket' with your actual bucket ID
Change 'temp' mapping to match your data field name
Adjust color (#FF5722) to match your dashboard theme
Update 'user' field with your username
Modify timespan value (24) to show different time ranges
Change panel colors (#1976D2) for different visual styles
Adjust sizeX (12 = full width) and sizeY (8) for widget sizing
Update title and subtitle to match your use case
Change yaxis formatter to match your units (°C, °F, etc.)

examples.title: Real-Time Device Resource (Live Data Stream)
examples.description: Real-time chart displaying live device resource data. Shows power consumption updated in real-time from a device resource endpoint.
examples.use_case: Real-time monitoring, live dashboards, instant alerts, streaming analytics
customization_notes: Replace 'smart_meters' with your product ID
Update 'meter_001' with your device ID
Change 'power_consumption' to your device resource name
Adjust 'power' mapping to match your resource output field
Modify color (#FFC107) for series visualization
Change timespan value (30 minutes) for different time windows
Update panel colors (#424242) to match dashboard theme
Adjust sizeX (6 = half width) and sizeY (6) for compact layout
Change chart type from 'area' to 'line' or 'bar' in options
Modify yaxis formatter to match your measurement units
Update title and subtitle for your specific use case
Note: Device must be connected and resource must exist

general_notes.colors: Use hexadecimal color codes (#RRGGBB) for consistent styling
general_notes.options_field: Must be JavaScript code string (not JSON). Escape newlines as \n, quotes as \'
general_notes.timestamps: Use Date.now() or current timestamp in milliseconds for updateTs
general_notes.tags_structure: MongoDB uses 'device' and 'group'. InfluxDB may have custom tags like 'Day', 'Hour', 'Slave', etc.
general_notes.timespan_requirement: Include both 'timespan' and '$timespan' objects for compatibility
general_notes.grid_layout: Standard grid is 12 columns wide. sizeX=6 is half width, sizeX=12 is full width
general_notes.user_field: Must include username who owns the bucket/device
general_notes.automatic_dashboard: Tool creates dashboard automatically if it doesn't exist

source_types_summary.bucket: Historical data from product-level data buckets (most common)
source_types_summary.device: Real-time data from device resource endpoints
